etymologies: early 16th century (in an earlier sense). Imitative. Compare West Frisian plof (noun and interjection), Dutch plof, both denoting various sounds produced by falling bodies or exploding gases

definitions: A strong puff or explosive emission of air, powder, smoke, etc., especially from the firing of a gun; (informal) a shot from a musket or hunting gun.
A tube through which air can be blown, especially a simple form of bellows (obsolete). Now English regional: specifically a pea-shooter, (also occasionally) a popgun.
Puffed up, swollen; soft, spongy. Also figurative. Now chiefly in "pluff mud" noun US, regional (chiefly South Carolina) a type of soft, silty mud found in tidal marshes.
Representing a puffing or explosive sound. Also as adverb: with a pluff.

notes.text: Sc. National Dict. (1968) s.v. records the adverbial use as still in use in Aberdeenshire, Angusshire, and Shetland in 1966.

etymologies: early 17th century; earliest use found in Zachary Boyd (1585–1653), Church of Scotland minister and university administrator. Imitative

definitions: To puff; to blow out with a puff, especially suddenly or explosively. Also with object: to blow or propel (something) from the mouth or through a tube. Formerly (Scottish): specifically †to fire a gun, to shoot (obsolete).
To swell up, become puffed up. Frequently with up.
